episode_summary: This episode, recorded at the Hay Festival, features literary-themed facts. The hosts discuss the first novel ending mid-sentence, Tolkien and Lewis attending a party as polar bears, Agatha Christie's disdain for Poirot, and John Logie Baird's pre-television inventions.

facts.fact: The first ever novel ended mid-sentence. This is a Japanese novel called The Tale of Genji, written in the early 11th century.
JRR Tolkien and CS Lewis went to a party dressed as Polar Bears. It was not a fancy dress party.
Agatha Christie thought that Hercules Poirot, her most famous creation, was a, quote, "detestable, bombastic, tiresome, egocentric little creep."
Before he invented the television, John Logie Baird invented a pair of socks to wear underneath your socks.
